Award.AwardTitle: FIA: Collaborative Research: MobilityFirst: A Robust and Trustworthy Mobility-Centric Architecture for the Future Internet

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is aimed at the design and experimental validation of a comprehensive clean-slate future Internet architecture. The proposed MobilityFirst architecture is motivated by the ongoing paradigm shift of Internet usage from today?s fixed PC/host (client)?server model to emerging mobile data services and pervasive computing applications. The major design goals of the architecture are: mobility as the norm with dynamic host and network mobility at scale; robustness with respect to intrinsic properties of the wireless medium; trustworthiness in the form of enhanced security and privacy; usability features such as support for context-aware services, evolvability, manageability and economic viability. The key components of the MobilityFirst network design are: (1) separation of naming and addressing, implemented via a fast global dynamic name resolution service; (2) self-certifying public key network addresses to support strong authentication and security; (3) generalized delay-tolerant routing with in-network storage for packets in transit; (4) flat-label internetwork routing with public key addresses; (5) hop-by-hop transport protocols operating over segments rather than an end-to-end path; (6) a separate network management plane that provides enhanced visibility; (7) optional privacy features for user and location data; and (8) an integrated computing and storage layer to support programmability. The project?s scope includes architectural design, validation of key protocol components, testbed prototyping of the MobilityFirst architecture as a whole, and real-world protocol deployment on the GENI experimental infrastructure. The results of this project will provide architectural guidance for cellular-Internet convergence, and are expected to influence future technical standards in the networking industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the support of this FIA award, we have worked with Rutgers University and other participating institutions on the MobilityFirst (MF) architecture, which is a clean-slate design of future Internet to address the mobility and security challenges. As part of the MF project, the UMass Lowell team worked on the design and implementation of the host protocol stack and a network API that supports profiles for the applications to describe their intent when interacting with the network. The experimental results show that our design and prototype achieved supreme performance than current TCP/IP-based Internet stack. To explore emerging mobile applications that may be supported by MF architecture, we studied a variety of context-aware mobile applications that take advantage of sensors in commodity smartphones and wearable devices. We envision a class of “companion” intelligent applications that continuously sense, learn, and reason the user’s activities, routines, and intentions. Thus these companions can proactively and opportunistically interact with the user to make recommendations helping the user achieving her life goals, such as to maintain an active lifestyle. These apps likely need cloud capability for better storage and faster computation, and thus will require capable and secure network access. To meet the technical requirements of such companion applications, we have developed energy-efficient continuous location tracking algorithms, a lightweight app and network measurement framework, cloud-based smart photo management application, and dynamic app launcher leveraging user’s location and other contextual data.

 

Through this project, we had the opportunity to directly involve 5 PhD students, 1 Master student, and 1 Undergraduate student. All PhD students read extensively about future Internet architecture, mobile systems and applications. They have also learned how to write and present research papers at major conferences, and they have participated in student research exhibition at UMass Lowell by displaying research posters. The Master student was inspired to apply for the PhD program and the undergraduate student started a successful career in Silicon Valley. The PI has also incorporated Future Internet materials in the graduate Data Communications courses. The outcomes of this research include 8 conference publications, 1 technical report, 2 PhD dissertations, 4 Android apps. We have also filed a provisional patent for the energy-efficient location tracking technology for commodity Android devices, which has also won UMass Lowell’s development funds for further commercialization efforts.
